\section{Copyright Declaration}

The copyright of this thesis rests with the author and is made available under a Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives licence. Researchers are free to copy, distribute or transmit the thesis on the condition that they attribute it, that they do not use it for commercial purposes and that they do not alter, transform or build upon it. For any reuse or redistribution, researchers must make clear to others the licence terms of this work.

\section{First result chapter}
\label{chap-reschap1}

\subsection{Mathematical Model}

Something smart\footnote{At least it should be something smart, not mystical like \cite{ExampleArticle1984}.}. The author of \cite{EmmitBrown1955} enjoyed reading and was inspired by \cite{TwentyThousandLeaguesUnderTheSea}.

\subsection{Some Notes on Figures}

Have a look at Figure \cite{fig-basis-fun-cg} and \cite{fig-rotation-schematic}. But also check out Figure \cite{fig-basis-functions}@subfig-basis-fun-cg and \cite{fig-basis-functions}@subfig-basis-fun-dg which includes two subfigures in one figure environment using the LaTeX package subcaption.

Example of including programming code is shown in Program @prog-some-program-label on page @prog-some-program-label.

\subsection{More text}

1-3

\section{Second result chapter}
\label{chap-reschap2}

\subsection{Mathematical Model}

Something smart, see \cite{EmmitBrown1947}. Also, see Table \cite{tab-scientists} on page .

Also have a look at Figures \cite{fig-test-combinations}, \cite{fig-some-results-plot}, and \cite{fig-3dgraphic}. These are good examples for TikZ graphics/pgfplots.

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering

\caption{This is a table of three scientists}
\label{tab-scientists}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\includegraphics{missing-image.pdf}
\caption{Fancy TikZ plot}
\label{fig-test-combinations}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering

\caption{PGFPlots reading in data from data files, then plotting it, with magnifying a certain area of the plot.}
\label{fig-some-results-plot}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\includegraphics{missing-image.pdf}
\caption{Another fancy 3d TikZ plot 3d}
\label{fig-3dgraphic}
\end{figure}

\section{Third result chapter}
\label{chap-reschap3}

\subsection{Mathematical Model}

Something smart, \cite{DoeJane2001}. Also, see the sideways printed Table \cite{tab-parefficiencybig} on page .

Moreover, Figure \cite{fig-parefficiency} shows another example of pgfplots beautifully plotting data from a data file. Table @tab-parefficiency shows the same data as a table.

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering
\includegraphics{missing-image.pdf}
\label{fig-parefficiency}
\end{figure}

\begin{figure}[H]
\centering

\caption{Same as Table \{tab:parefficiency\}, but with more columns to stretch the width such that it has to be rotated to fit on one page.}
\label{tab-parefficiencybig}
\end{figure}
